Award.AwardTitle: Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for the 2017 Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium that will take place at the University of Texas at Austin in the 2017 fall semester. The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium is a regional weekend meeting held annually, hosted in turn by Rice University, the University of Texas at Austin, and occasionally other institutions in the region. It is intended for the participation of around 60 people, including 25 non-local graduate students. The workshop brings together many senior mathematicians from Texas and neighboring states, who may not otherwise have an opportunity to discuss mathematics together throughout the year. Structurally the symposium consists of 7 main lectures given by nationally recognized leaders in the field, and contributed sessions (including a poster session) for advanced graduate students and participating researchers from regional universities, to present their work. This will provide graduate students with an opportunity to obtain feedback from senior faculty from other departments. The networking activities made possible by the Symposium will prove to be a valuable experience for young researchers. The Symposium encourages and financially supports participation by students, recent Ph.D. recipients, and members of groups underrepresented in mathematics. The Symposium is a forum for regional specialists in mathematical physics and related areas of analysis to become familiar with the latest problems and present their own results; in addition it introduces young mathematicians to the current state of the subject.

This year's Symposium will focus on the areas where dispersive partial differential equations, statistical mechanics, and harmonic analysis intersect and interact. More information, including a list of speakers and abstracts, registration information, and an archive of the past symposium can be found at the website of the meeting:

https://www.ma.utexas.edu/users/tc/TeXAMP/TeXAMP-2017/TeXAMP-2017.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Texas Analysis and Mathematical Physics Symposium 2017 was the fifth in this conference series, and took place on Nov 3-5, 2017, at the University of Texas at Austin.

The invited talks were presented by David Damanik (Rice University; Some surprises in the spectral theory of almost-periodic Schrodinger operators), Irene Gamba (UT Austin; Common features between the quantum Boltzmann equation cold regimes and the wave turbulence model for stratified flows), Michael Kiessling (Rutgers University; General relativity at the (sub-)atomic scale), Matei Machedon (University of Maryland; Pair excitation and the mean field approximation of interacting Bosons), Irina Nenciu (University of Illinois at Chicago; On some concrete criteria for quantum and stochastic confinement), Lenya Ryzhik (Stanford University; The random heat equation in dimensions three and higher), Avy Soffer (Rutgers University; Supercritical wave equations), Christof Sparber (University of Illinois at Chicago; Weakly nonlinear time- adiabatic theory).

In addition, we organized five sessions of contributed talks: In Session 1 (Spectral theory of Schrodinger operators), the speakers were Gokalp Alpan, Valmir Bucaj, Manuela Girotti, Artem Hulko, Tom VandenBoom. In Session 2 (Nonlinear PDEs and Mathematical Physics), the speakers were Siming He, Michael Hott, Donghong Zhao, Yulia Meshkova, Jacky Chong. In Session 3 (Kinetic Theory and Fluids), the speakers were Sam Krupa, Jin Woo Jang, Zhihong Zhao, Jing Tian, Ryan Denlinger. In Session 4 (Quantum Chaos and Integrable Systems), the speakers were Jon Harrison, Pedro Morales, Brian Simanek, Juan Lopez, Erica Swindle. In Session 5 (Statistical Physics and Further Topics), the speakers were Arun Debray, Christoph Fischbacher, Minh Kha, Selim Sukhtaiev, Wei Wang.
